title: AutoGen vs Make: Which workflow automation Tool is Better in 2026?
metaDescription: Compare AutoGen vs Make. See pricing, features, pros & cons to choose the best workflow automation tool for your needs in 2026.
introduction: Choosing between AutoGen and Make for your workflow automation needs? Both are popular tools in the AI space, but they have different strengths, pricing models, and use cases. This comprehensive comparison breaks down the key differences to help you make an informed decision.

sections.title: Overview: AutoGen vs Make
paragraphs: AutoGen is AutoGen is an open-source framework from Microsoft Research for building and orchestrating multi-agent AI systems. It enables developers to create, manage, and coordinate multiple conversational AI agents—each with specialized roles, capabilities, and tools—to collaboratively solve complex tasks through structured dialogue. Its unique value lies in its flexible, code-centric approach to agent definition and its seamless integration with human oversight, making it a powerful tool for automating intricate workflows that require reasoning, tool use, and iterative problem-solving.. It's known for multi-agent-systems, conversational-ai, workflow-automation.

Make, on the other hand, is Make (formerly Integromat) is a visual workflow automation platform that simplifies business process automation. In April 2025, Make introduced AI Agents for plain-language instruction-based automation. The platform emphasizes user-friendly experience and reliability for non-technical users.. Users choose it for workflow-automation, ai-agents, integration.

sections.title: Pricing Comparison
paragraphs: When it comes to value for money, consider your specific use case and team size.  Make also has a free option for small teams or individuals.

sections.title: Features & Capabilities
paragraphs: AutoGen excels in: Customizable, conversable agent programming with adjustable LLM backends (OpenAI, Azure OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.), Built-in support for role-based agent patterns (e.g., Assistant, UserProxy, GroupChat) with customizable system prompts, Seamless code execution, debugging, and human-in-the-loop feedback within agent conversations. This makes it ideal for teams that need multi-agent-systems.
Make stands out with: AI Agents for plain-language automation, Visual workflow builder, 400+ app integrations. It's particularly strong for users focused on workflow-automation.

sections.title: Use Cases: When to Choose Each Tool
paragraphs: Choose AutoGen if: You need multi-agent-systems, work with conversational-ai, or require flexible pricing.
Choose Make if: You prioritize workflow-automation, work in ai-agents, or prefer a free tier to start.

sections.title: Pros & Cons
paragraphs: AutoGen Pros: Verified platform, Highly rated (4.7/5), Extensive feature set.
AutoGen Cons: Some limitations on free tier.
Make Pros: Verified platform, Featured tool, Highly rated (4.7/5), Comprehensive features.
Make Cons: May have feature limitations.

verdict: Both AutoGen and Make are solid choices for workflow automation. Your choice depends on your specific requirements: AutoGen is better for multi-agent-systems, while Make excels at workflow-automation. Consider trying both with their free tiers or trials to see which fits your workflow better.
